Vegetation, disrob'd of her charms,</br>In verdure no longer is drest;</br>The sun has deserted her arms,</br>And mantles no more, on her breast:</br>But the ever green frowning and rude,</br>In foliage deep darken'd I spy,</br>And the mosses with fruitage endued</br>Give pleasure to Botany's eye.

The bat, in this season of gloom,</br>In death-like torpidity lost,</br>Immur'd in her membranous tomb,</br>Defies the return of the frost.</br>From yonder old ivy-bound pile</br>The red-breast, last friend to the plain,</br>The desolate day to beguile,</br>Pays his lone but enlivening strain.

Untouch'd and unblest were my mind,</br>Mid sullen dark shades of the eve,</br>Could I not some circumstance find,</br>When dirgeful the cricket shall grieve.</br>Then come, Contemplation, explore</br>Our toils, and our vanities too,</br>False pleasures, which ebb from the shore,</br>As we the gay phantoms pursue.

Soft Nurse of Reflection, thy power</br>Can dissipate solitude's shade,</br>And brighten December's dark hour,</br>By Nature's obituary made.</br>Thy whispers, sobriety's Queen,</br>Are hymns to this ear of my mind;</br>Delightfully fair is thy mien,</br>By Wisdom and Reason refin'd.

Advanc'd Desolations appear;</br>December, how chearless thy frown!</br>The knell of the fast-flowing year</br>Depresses both village and town.</br>Meditations, O come from thy cell,</br>Tho' Nature seems prone to decay,</br>Thy presence her fears shall dispel,</br>And lengthen the short-living day.

Emotions which flow from thy song,</br>Most welcome and pang-soothing guest,</br>The blessings of hope shall prolong</br>The mind of depressions divest.</br>What tho' the pale Season denies</br>Those beauties which brighten the spring,</br>On pinions borne down from the skies—</br>'Tis thine pure Contentment to bring.

When odours replenish the gale,</br>The streamlets run purling along,</br>The Zephyrs dissuasive prevail,</br>And Philomel issue her song.</br>The music of nature display'd</br>In note unambitiously wild,</br>The fawns skip and bound in the glade,</br>And all is most placid and mild.

When Flora awakens the flowers,</br>Her children of purest perfume,</br>Descend in refreshment the showers,</br>To nurture the Innocent bloom:</br>Aetherial mildness around</br>Revives with congenial ray,</br>Enamels the spring garnish'd ground,</br>And Pleasure leads forward the day.

When the landscape with transport descried</br>Bright summer presents to the view,</br>In robes too expressive of pride,</br>Tho' the mirror of Nature is true;</br>When Autumn hard labour repays,</br>And plenty diffuses her crops,</br>Wide scatters her silver-soft rays</br>Thro' gardens thick-cluster'd with hops.

When Summer, or Autumn, or Spring,</br>Their treasures alternate dispense,</br>Vicissitudes pleasing you bring,</br>The grateful remembrance of Sense.</br>But Winter, tho' wrapt in a cloud,</br>A gratitude warmer excites;</br>All Nature proclaims it aloud,</br>December is fraught with delights.

To earth shall some Seraphs of Love,</br>In tide of full harmony pour</br>His mandates commission'd above</br>The race of mankind to restore.</br>On pinions of rapture he brings</br>The mercies of unbounded space,</br>As stream from empyreal strings</br>His missions of peace and of grace.

Devotion, elate of the sound,</br>Her incense prepares for the morn,</br>When tidings of gladness around</br>Proclaim a Messiah was born;</br>Superlative news to the breast</br>Replete with this knowledge divine,</br>Where thy virtues, dear Innocence, rest,</br>And Religion's best triumphs are thine.

Let warm acclamations ascend,</br>Festivity, Reason, be near,</br>And Charity, Virtue's own friend,</br>The head of pale sorrow uprear!</br>Let Wealth all her scorn lay aside,</br>To Poverty's residence go,</br>And practice the soul-lifting pride,</br>In robbing distress of a woe.</br>
